citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
One adult zebu is missing its right horn and has a dried, healing wound where it had broken. The facility stated that the
injury happened a couple weeks ago and that they had treated it with topical medication. The facility representative stated
that they did not contact the attending veterinarian and the Program of Veterinary Care does not contain any guidance
regarding treatment.
Injuries like broken horns can cause pain to the animal. The facility must ensure the use of appropriate methods to
prevent, control, diagnose, and treat diseases and injuries. The facility must contact the veterinarian and use medications
as directed.
To be corrected from this day, January 14, 2025, forward.

At the time of inspection, the facility does not have updated records of acquisition and disposition. The facility is missing
the acquisition records for three porcupines and one blue-and-gold macaw as well as the disposition record for one
hedgehog.
Appropriate documentation of regulated animals is essential for proper identification, tracking of animals and for APHIS
Officials to be able to carry out their duties. Exhibitors shall make and maintain complete records regarding the details of
the acquisition and disposition of animals in their possession in order to account for all animal transfers or deaths and the
sources of the animals.
To be corrected by January 21, 2025.

Inside the enclosure housing one white-throated capuchin, there is a live electrical cord for the heating lamp that the
animal has damaged. According to the facility representative, the cord had been suspended above the enclosure;
however, at the time of inspection, the capuchin had managed to pull it into the enclosure and strip off the outer layer of
the cord to expose the wires inside. The facility representative removed the cord during the inspection.
In the enclosure housing two squirrel monkeys, there are multiple electrical cords along the top that the animals can
access. The electrical cord for the heating mat is also accessible to the animals inside the enclosure. In one corner of the
enclosure, the facility has filled in gaps with foam insulation that the animals can access. The insulation appears to have
been picked at and is missing chunks from the surface.
Allowing nonhuman primates access to inappropriate materials, such as insulation, can lead to ingestion, illness, or
blockage of the intestinal tract. Access to electrical cords can cause injury or death if pulled or chewed on by the animals.
Primary enclosures must be constructed and maintained so that they protect the nonhuman primates from injury.
To be corrected by January 21, 2025.

citations.desc: Environment enhancement to promote psychological well-being.
citations.narrative:
The environment enhancement plan for nohuman primates at the facility is inadequate. It does not address social
grouping, special considerations, restraint devices, or exemptions and there is minimal information regarding
environmental enrichment.
Failure to establish and maintain an adequate plan for environment enhancement can result in the behavioral, social, and
psychological needs of the nonhuman primates not being met. The plan must address at a minimum social grouping,
environment enrichment, special considerations, restraint devices, and any nonhuman primates that are exempted by the
attending veterinarian because of health issues or other conditions. The facility must establish and maintain an
environment enhancement plan for the nonhuman primates.
To be corrected by February 11, 2025.

Multiple enclosures are not being kept in good repair.
-In an enclosure housing two pigs, there is a wooden shelter that is deteriorating. The shelter has broken wood and there
are screw points exposed where the animals can access them.
-In the enclosure housing two adult porcupines, there is crumpled chain link that has sharp points where the animals can
access them.
-Between the two camel enclosures, there is a metal gate that is broken and leaning. On the shelter for the male camel,
there is a broken metal grate that is hanging in the entrance.
-There is baling twine from feeding hay in multiple enclosures, including a pen containing seven goats and a cow, a pen
containing two cows, and a pen containing three zebu.
-In the enclosure housing one cavy, there is a metal support pole that has rusted through. This has created an opening
that has jagged edges that the animal can access.
-In the enclosure housing one opossum, there is a wooden beam that has rotted through. This has exposed nails and
screws which the animal can access. There is also an electrical wire for the heating pad that the animal can access.
-In the enclosure housing two kinkajous, there are multiple wooden beams that have rotted through. This has exposed
nails and screws which the animals can access.
-In the enclosure housing several goats and a llama, there is crumbled chicken wire inside the pen creating sharp points
that the animals can access.
Enclosures that contain inappropriate materials or are not kept in good repair can result in injury to the animals from sharp
points, ingestion, entanglement, or electrocution. The facility must be constructed of such material and of such strength as
appropriate for the animals involved. The housing facilities shall be maintained in good repair to protect the animals from
injury and to contain the animals.
To be corrected by February 4, 2025.

citations.desc: Environment enhancement to promote psychological well-being.
citations.narrative:
At the time of inspection, an environment enhancement plan has not been established to promote the psychological well-
being of the birds.
Failure to establish and maintain a plan for environment enhancement can result in the behavioral, social, and
psychological needs of the birds not being met. The plan must address at a minimum social grouping, environment
enrichment, special considerations, restraint devices, and any birds that are exempted by the attending veterinarian
because of health issues or other conditions. The plan must be approved by the attending veterinarian. The facility must
establish and maintain an environment enhancement plan for the birds.
To be corrected by February 11, 2025.
This is a continuation of the report for the routine inspection conducted 13 JAN 2025 and contains the remaining non-
compliances found during the inspection. The exit briefing for the items included on this report was conducted on 13 JAN
2025.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with on 13 JAN 2025 with a facility representative.
n

narrative:
2.40(b)(2) 
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
One adult zebu is missing its right horn and has a dried, healing wound where it had broken. The facility stated that the 
injury happened a couple weeks ago and that they had treated it with topical medication. The facility representative stated 
that they did not contact the attending veterinarian and the Program of Veterinary Care does not contain any guidance

Injuries like broken horns can cause pain to the animal. The facility must ensure the use of appropriate methods to 
prevent, control, diagnose, and treat diseases and injuries. The facility must contact the veterinarian and use medications 
as directed.  
To be corrected from this day, January 14, 2025, forward. 
2.75(b)(1) 
   
Records: Dealers and exhibitors. 
At the time of inspection, the facility does not have updated records of acquisition and disposition. The facility is missing 
the acquisition records for three porcupines and one blue-and-gold macaw as well as the disposition record for one 
hedgehog. 
Appropriate documentation of regulated animals is essential for proper identification, tracking of animals and for APHIS

the acquisition and disposition of animals in their possession in order to account for all animal transfers or deaths and the 
sources of the animals.  
To be corrected by January 21, 2025. 
3.80(a)(2)(ii) 
   
Primary enclosures. 
Inside the enclosure housing one white-throated capuchin, there is a live electrical cord for the heating lamp that the 
animal has damaged. According to the facility representative, the cord had been suspended above the enclosure; 
however, at the time of inspection, the capuchin had managed to pull it into the enclosure and strip off the outer layer of 
the cord to expose the wires inside. The facility representative removed the cord during the inspection. 
In the enclosure housing two squirrel monkeys, there are multiple electrical cords along the top that the animals can 
access. The electrical cord for the heating mat is also accessible to the animals inside the enclosure. In one corner of the

enclosure, the facility has filled in gaps with foam insulation that the animals can access. The insulation appears to have 
been picked at and is missing chunks from the surface. 
Allowing nonhuman primates access to inappropriate materials, such as insulation, can lead to ingestion, illness, or 
blockage of the intestinal tract. Access to electrical cords can cause injury or death if pulled or chewed on by the animals. 
Primary enclosures must be constructed and maintained so that they protect the nonhuman primates from injury.  
To be corrected by January 21, 2025. 
3.81 
   
Environment enhancement to promote psychological well-being. 
The environment enhancement plan for nohuman primates at the facility is inadequate. It does not address social 
grouping, special considerations, restraint devices, or exemptions and there is minimal information regarding 
environmental enrichment. 
Failure to establish and maintain an adequate plan for environment enhancement can result in the behavioral, social, and 
psychological needs of the nonhuman primates not being met. The plan must address at a minimum social grouping, 
environment enrichment, special considerations, restraint devices, and any nonhuman primates that are exempted by the 
attending veterinarian because of health issues or other conditions. The facility must establish and maintain an 
environment enhancement plan for the nonhuman primates.  
To be corrected by February 11, 2025. 
3.125(a) 
   
Facilities, general. 
Multiple enclosures are not being kept in good repair.  
-In an enclosure housing two pigs, there is a wooden shelter that is deteriorating. The shelter has broken wood and there 
are screw points exposed where the animals can access them.  
-In the enclosure housing two adult porcupines, there is crumpled chain link that has sharp points where the animals can 
access them.  
-Between the two camel enclosures, there is a metal gate that is broken and leaning. On the shelter for the male camel, 
there is a broken metal grate that is hanging in the entrance.  
-There is baling twine from feeding hay in multiple enclosures, including a pen containing seven goats and a cow, a pen 
containing two cows, and a pen containing three zebu. 
-In the enclosure housing one cavy, there is a metal support pole that has rusted through. This has created an opening 
that has jagged edges that the animal can access.  
-In the enclosure housing one opossum, there is a wooden beam that has rotted through. This has exposed nails and 
screws which the animal can access. There is also an electrical wire for the heating pad that the animal can access.  
-In the enclosure housing two kinkajous, there are multiple wooden beams that have rotted through. This has exposed 
nails and screws which the animals can access. 
-In the enclosure housing several goats and a llama, there is crumbled chicken wire inside the pen creating sharp points 
that the animals can access.  
Enclosures that contain inappropriate materials or are not kept in good repair can result in injury to the animals from sharp 
points, ingestion, entanglement, or electrocution. The facility must be constructed of such material and of such strength as 
appropriate for the animals involved. The housing facilities shall be maintained in good repair to protect the animals from

injury and to contain the animals. 
To be corrected by February 4, 2025. 
3.154 
   
Environment enhancement to promote psychological well-being. 
At the time of inspection, an environment enhancement plan has not been established to promote the psychological well-
being of the birds.  
Failure to establish and maintain a plan for environment enhancement can result in the behavioral, social, and 
psychological needs of the birds not being met. The plan must address at a minimum social grouping, environment 
enrichment, special considerations, restraint devices, and any birds that are exempted by the attending veterinarian 
because of health issues or other conditions. The plan must be approved by the attending veterinarian. The facility must 
establish and maintain an environment enhancement plan for the birds.  
To be corrected by February 11, 2025. 
 
This is a continuation of the report for the routine inspection conducted 13 JAN 2025 and contains the remaining non-
compliances found during the inspection. The exit briefing for the items included on this report was conducted on 13 JAN 
2025. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with on 13 JAN 2025 with a facility representative.
